awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Programming Dynamic Growth and Reconfiguration in Nucleic Acid Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical: This CAREER Award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to the University of California, Riverside will be used to develop responsive, programmable materials made with RNA and synthetic genes. Biological organisms control their shape in space and time by producing and directing the assembly of molecular building blocks with molecular circuits. The cellular scaffold, for instance, grows and reorganizes its shape in response to environmental stimuli that trigger the production of the scaffold materials and the molecules that regulate its organization. Reproducing the properties of cellular scaffolds in synthetic materials will advance our ability to manipulate matter at the nanoscale and create reconfigurable, regenerating materials. However, cellular materials are too complex to be directly embedded in a man-made material, and chemical synthesis of active assembling materials is very laborious. In contrast, DNA and RNA are highly programmable polymers that can be used to build self-assembling structures as well as molecular control circuits. The overall objective of this project is to couple RNA structures and circuits to build dynamic RNA nanomaterials encoded in minimal artificial DNA gene networks; experiments and modeling will be combined to achieve this objective. RNA nanostructures will be assembled from monomers (tiles) produced by artificial genes. Timed assembly and disassembly instructions will also be encoded in RNA signals generated by synthetic gene networks, resulting in a new generation of smart materials capable of growth, metamorphosis, and self-repair. This grant will support graduate and undergraduate students to perform cutting edge research in biomaterials science. The PI and her team of students will also collaborate with the University of California Television (UCTV), and the UC Riverside Media Relations office to produce short educational clips to be aired on UCTV.

Technical:  This research project aims at building active, programmable nucleic acid biomaterials encoded in synthetic genes. Modular RNA nanostructures (tubes and ribbons) will be designed to self-assemble from monomers (tiles) and grow, self-regulate and repair. Production and control pathways will be embedded in transcriptional circuits and only involve  DNA, RNA and off-the-shelf proteins. Mathematical models will elucidate design principles and guide experiments. This research has the potential to transform current methods to design and build synthetic materials, because these RNA dynamic nanostructures will be produced, self-assembled, and regulated from a finite number of components, rather than being synthesized with a top-down approach.  This approach mimics the organization of cellular pathways for the synthesis and control of molecular materials such as the cytoskeleton: however, our materials will be rationally designed and built, exploiting the programmability of nucleic acids. This project is integrated with an outreach program aimed at disseminating research results and at inspiring high school and undergraduate students to pursue higher education through the production of educational materials and short video clips in collaboration with the University of California Television (UCTV), and the UC Riverside Media Relations office.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed methods to build scalable RNA self-assembling materials by programming base-pairing interactions. We achieved this by leveraging techniques demonstrated in the field of DNA nanotechnology, which we adapted to the structural and biochemical properties of RNA.

In the first part of the project (located at the University of California, Riverside), our research focused on developing RNA tile motifs. These RNA tiles form through the interactions of multiple RNA strands whose sequences are designed through a computer program that maximizes the interaction energies of specific domains while minimizing unwanted secondary structure. We demonstrated that RNA tiles including only 3 distinct strands can assemble into tubes and lattices, and we characterized the influence of various design parameters of the tiles on the outcome of the assembly. A notable finding was that some designs yield chiral tubular structures exceeding several microns in length. We also showed that these RNA scaffolds can be decorated with siRNA molecules, and delivered to living cells to control gene expression. We further modified our RNA tile motifs to include 5 short distinct strands and varied additional tile parameters, demonstrating the formation of synthetic RNA filaments and nanotubes that to our knowledge are the largest RNA assemblies ever obtained.

In the second part of the project (located at the University of California, Los Angeles, where the Franco group moved in 2018), we refocused the scope of the research toward the synthesis of amorphous DNA and RNA condensates that emerge as phase separated droplets in liquid samples. The reason for this shift is that we sought to build RNA materials that could be potentially produced in living cells under physiological conditions, while the RNA tile motifs characterized in the first part of the project require thermal annealing to form. We began this new direction of the project by developing methods to dynamically operate DNA condensates. We adopted star-shaped motifs (nanostars) comprising 3 distinct DNA strands. These nanostars interact via short, palindromic sticky ends, generating an amorphous network that phase separates into DNA-dense droplets. First, we discovered that condensate growth rate scales with the nanostar arm length. We found that this is a general property in condensing materials, as indicated by theory and computational simulations. Next, we demonstrated methods to activate and deactivate DNA nanostars via strand displacement, showing that condensate formation can be controlled kinetically and reversibly through biochemical reactions.  In addition to experiments, we developed a general continuum model that examines the well-known Cahn Hilliard theory for phase separation in the presence of chemical reactions, and studied how the reactions can affect the system’s phase transitions and the growth patterns of condensates.

Finally, we developed an RNA single-stranded equivalent of DNA nanostars. These RNA nanostars interact with kissing loops (KL) and their sequences are designed with computer programs. We characterized the phase separation of purified RNA nanostars under thermal annealing, examining the influence of different KL and arm sequences, and we developed two-nanostar systems that have non-palindromic KL. These nanostars were further decorated with fluorogenic aptamers, and we showed that sequence-orghogonal nanostars yield distinct condensates that do not mix. We also showed that these RNA condensates form during transcription at constant temperature, and do not require thermal annealing. This project serves as the basis for current and future studies aimed at controlling the kinetics of formation of RNA condensates, as well as expressing these RNA condensates within living cells.

Overall, this project provided training and support to 4 Ph.D. students and 2 undergraduate students. The PI and the students contributed to multiple educational and  outreach initiatives at K-12 institutions in the California Inland Empire, and delivered more than 5 presentations at workshops engaging high school students as part of IEEE and AACC international conferences.

 


Last Modified: 08/18/2023
Modified by: Elisa Franco
